authors: Galvan, A., Hare, T. A., Parra, C. E., Penn, J., Voss, H., Glover, G., & Casey, B. J.
title: Earlier development of the accumbens relative to orbitofrontal cortex might underlie risk-taking behavior in adolescents.

authors: Galvan, A., Hare, T., Voss, H., Glover, G., & Casey, B. J.
title: Risk-taking and the adolescent brain: who is at risk?
outcome: after selecting a brain region based on sensitivity to reward magnitude, we found that activity in this region during reward correlated with self-report of engaging in behaviors for which people expected to be rewarded. Essentially asking, if you take Nacc as �liking rewards�: How much do you like rewards? And correlating it with: How much do you think you�d do things that you think will be rewarding?
finding: correlation between Nacc activity �A priori ROI� and CARE questionnaire � that is expected involvement in rewarding activities predicted by reward sensitive neural region.

authors: Duijvenvoorde, A. C. K. van, Zanolie, K., Rombouts, S. A. R. B., Raijmakers, M. E. J., & Crone, E. A.
title: Evaluating the Negative or Valuing the Positive? Neural Mechanisms Supporting Feedback-Based Learning across Development.
finding: Adults are better than early adolescents are better than children. Better performance on positive feedback trials.

authors: Van Den Bos, W., G�ro?lu, B., Van Den Bulk, B. G., Rombouts, S. A., & Crone, E. A.
title: Better than expected or as bad as you thought? The neurocognitive development of probabilistic feedback processing.
notes: same sample as van den bos 2012

authors: Cohen, J. R., Asarnow, R. F., Sabb, F. W., Bilder, R. M., Bookheimer, S. Y., Knowlton, B. J., & Poldrack, R. A.
title: A unique adolescent response to reward prediction errors.
notes: Accuracy percent on predictable trials (last block) for children, adol, adul: 68.3(18.7) 79.8(15.1) 84.1(16.0)

authors: van den Bos, W., Cohen, M. X., Kahnt, T., & Crone, E. A.
title: Striatum�Medial Prefrontal Cortex Connectivity Predicts Developmental Changes in Reinforcement Learning.
finding: Age related decrease in learning rate for negative feedback
learning rate: negative:  adol = adul; positive adol ~< adul
notes: same sample as van den bos 2009

authors: Christakou, A., Gershman, S. J., Niv, Y., Simmons, A., Brammer, M., & Rubia, K.
title: Neural and Psychological Maturation of Decision-making in Adolescence and Young Adulthood.
feedback: �money� reward or loss for cards chosen
finding: performance (beneficial decisions) increases with age. �The maturation profile of both [learning rate] parameters echoed their relationship with performance: sensitivity to positive PEs decreased with increasing age across the whole sample, r(35) = ?0.328, p < .05. Conversely, sensitivity to negative PEs increased with age, but only across adolescence, r(16) = 0.567, p < .05, not in adulthood, r(17) = 0.093, p = ns, echoing the pattern of developmental improvement in performance.�
learning rate: Depends on whether feedback is positive or negative. Smaller learning rate with age, for positive feedback; bigger learning rate with age, for negative feedback.

authors: Jones, R. M., Somerville, L. H., Li, J., Ruberry, E. J., Powers, A., Mehta, N., � Casey, B. J.
title: Adolescent-specific patterns of behavior and neural activity during social reinforcement learning.
learning task: probabilistic instrumental learning � participant had to respond to face with which side eye had winked, and then they were reinforced with an indication that they had �received� a note from the winking peer (3 total peers).
optimal response: no particular response required for earning reward (any response to wink counted)
finding: accelerating quadratic for learning rate, with highest learning rate in childhood, looking like it asymptotes in adulthood. But the outcome is reaction time so�.
notes: no performance measure (reaction time not necessarily measure of performance). No descriptive reaction time data presented.

authors: Davidow, J. Y., Foerde, K., Galv�n, A., & Shohamy, D.
title: An Upside to Reward Sensitivity: The Hippocampus Supports Enhanced Reinforcement Learning in Adolescence.
learning task: Butterfly cue, choose one of two flowers.
feedback: correct or incorrect, with image to be tested later for recognition
optimal response: Highest probabilistically associated choice (probably about P = .80)
finding: adolescents choose optimal choice more often than adults by task end, and have lower learning rate

authors: Palminteri, S., Kilford, E. J., Coricelli, G., & Blakemore, S.-J.
title: The Computational Development of Reinforcement Learning during Adolescence.

finding: Actually, no evidence of reward sensitivity as measured by Nacc related to alcohol use � this is one of a bunch of comparisons. �right NAcc activation explained significant variance in the average amount of glasses (B = .13, t = 2.01, p = .046)�

authors: Lockwood, P. L., Apps, M. A. J., Valton, V., Viding, E., & Roiser, J. P.
title: Neurocomputational mechanisms of prosocial learning and links to empathy.
journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
outcome: points earned, learning rate, inverse temperature
comparisons: conditions, with self as the control condition
finding: higher learning rate in self v prosoc or no-one condition, higher temperature in no-one condition, correlation with empathy subscale and prosocial-self learning rate
notes: Played for points for �self, someone else or no one�. The obvious finding is that people on average do better when they play for their own points. Not sure how garden-of-forking paths empathy correlation is (p = .01)

authors: Rosenblau, G., Korn, C. W., & Pelphrey, K. A.
title: A computational account of optimizing social predictions reveals that adolescents are conservative learners in social contexts.
learning task: Rating target preferences for 3 general categories of items: activity, fashion, food
optimal response: Same rating on item as target rating on item. Not clear if this is stable within subcategory
outcome: learning rates and prediction error (difference between actual target rating and participant-predicted rating)
finding: learning rate is smaller in adolsecents. Prediction error is on average lower in adults (adults perform better)

title: Increased striatal activity in adolescence benefits learning.
sample: Maybe 250 or so (736 scans over 3 waves)
outcome:
� Feedback-learning performance was defined as the
percentage of feedback during the learning phase, which was
successfully used on the next trial (stay for positive feedback,
switch for negative feedback).�
finding: learning ability improves across age from 10-30
notes: easy task (just remembering correct or incorrect feedback on last stimulus) leads to high accuracy all around, but younger people are not quite as good.

authors: Kamkar, N. H., Lewis, D. J., van den Bos, W., & Morton, J. B.
title: Ventral striatal activity links adversity and reward processing in children.
outcome: proportion choose A or avoid B
finding: �Adversity was positively correlated with reward-related learning, r(38) = 0.547, but not loss-related learning, r(38) = 0.189, p = 0.242�

authors: Kamkar, N. H., Lewis, D. J., van den Bos, W., & Morton, J. B.
title: Ventral striatal activity links adversity and reward processing in children.
finding: Total Adversity was positively associated with gain-pair, r(24) = 0.39, p = 0.048, but not loss-pair accuracy, r(24) = 0.25, p = 0.218

authors: McCormick, E. M., & Telzer, E. H.
title: Adaptive Adolescent Flexibility: Neurodevelopment of Decision-making and Learning in a Risky Context.

authors: Hanson, J. L., van den Bos, W., Roeber, B. J., Rudolph, K. D., Davidson, R. J., & Pollak, S. D.
title: Early adversity and learning: implications for typical and atypical behavioral development.
journal: Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry
outcome: Early adversity versus no early adversity
finding:
As expected, youths who suffered this early
adversity had higher rates of behavioral problems
than a community sample of their peers. The data
from this study provides new insights into why these
behavioral problems arise. First, the participants
who had been exposed to early adversity were less
able than their peers to correctly learn which stimuli
were likely to result in reward, even after repeated
feedback. This difficulty discerning and using information from the environment explained the higher
levels of behavioral problems in participants exposed
to early adversity, and was maintained even after
statistically controlling for adolescents� general
cognitive abilities.

title: Advice taking
learning task: IGT 4 decks, 2 good, 2 bad, one good deck recommended by �previous participant� before task start
finding: adolescents learning rate is smaller than or equal to adults (gains, losses; n.s.), while theta (temp) is higher in adults. Adult performance looks better

authors: Decker, J. H., Lourenco, F. S., Doll, B. B., & Hartley, C. A.
title: Experiential reward learning outweighs instruction prior to adulthood.
finding: Adults do best, but not significantly better then adolescents (but significantly better than children). Adults were more biased toward the false instruction
